header.title: Beltane
header.category: Pagan Sabbat, Seasonal Rituals, Fertility Magic

central_thesis: Beltane is a pivotal cross-quarter fire festival celebrating fertility, healing, the union of the God and Goddess, and the reawakening of vitality and passion, offering opportunities for self-discovery and personal growth.

structure_content.summary: Describes Beltane as the second fire festival, occurring late April/early May. Introduces the Horned God (Stag King, Oak King) entering manhood and ruling the light half of the year. Links the sabbat to Celtic god Bel and Greco-Roman goddess Maia. Highlights themes of fertility, healing, self-discovery, love, and union.

Details the great bonfire as a gate to other worlds. Mentions driving cattle through flames for blessing/healing, jumping over fires for luck (three times) and sealing vows for couples. Describes May morning as magical for wild water (dew, streams, springs) used for beauty/health. Mentions the May Pole as a fertility symbol and decorating homes/bodies with flowers. Concludes with the union of the God and Goddess, a wedding feast, and incense (frankincense, lilac, rose).

key_concepts.definition: A cross-quarter fire festival celebrated around late April/early May, marking the second fire festival.
The male deity figure who enters his manhood and begins his rule over the light half of the year during Beltane.
A central element of Beltane rituals, representing a "gate to other worlds" and used for blessings, healing, and sealing vows.
A focal point in old English village rituals, symbolic of fertility, decorated with flowers and branches.

practical_system.description: The article describes traditional and symbolic practices for celebrating Beltane, focusing on themes of fertility, healing, and the union of divine energies. It outlines specific actions to be taken during the festival to invoke these energies.
rituals: Driving cattle through flames (symbolic/modern adaptation implied)
Jumping over the fire three times for luck
Couples jumping over fire to seal vows
Collecting wild water on May morning for beauty/health

relevant_quotes.text: Beltane is the second of the fire festivals, celebrated around the end of April and the beginning of May, this is a greater Sabbat, a cross-quarter festival.
This sabbat is best known for fertility and healing, the great bonfire is represents the gate to other worlds.
The May pole is a focal point of many old English village rituals, symbolic of fertility.

critical_analysis.relevance: Provides a foundational understanding of Beltane from a modern Pagan/Wiccan perspective, emphasizing its core themes and traditional practices. Useful for practitioners planning Sabbat celebrations.
critical_analysis.target_audience: WiccaUK members, new and experienced Wiccans, Pagans interested in seasonal rituals, or those seeking an introduction to Beltane.
